I loved the story about the memory cams, which is a journalist testing out this new essentially external videeo memory interweaved with a story about a tribal man in Africa learning to read and how becoming literate completely changes his view on life. I loved the descriptions of what it meant to learn to read and write, and how it shifted the way the man thought about language but also the world. Which other stories did I like? The artificial nanny story was cute but didn't do too much for me. Anyway, it was really good, and I hope he writes more! Though I think we all agreed that N. K. Jemisin's stories tended to be stronger -- more character and plot, while also having good ideas. Ah well.

books.title: A Fortune for Your Disaster
books.author: Hanif Abdurraqib
books.notes: Phew, I read this over many, many months. Over a year? I got it because we were interested in discussing his poem 'How Can Black People Talk about Flowers at a Time Like This' on Valentina's podcast, and then realized he had several different poems with that title, so I bought the book and discovered he had *many* different poems by that title. I really liked the poems, but I found them kind of exhausting to read, hence dipping into it every few months and then abandoning it. Also the pandemic made it hard to read poetry, but I did finish other books (I think...) in this time, and this one kind of eluded me. Anyway, I finally finished it. Again, I really liked his rhythm, but the poems made me sad and tired.

books.title: The Crying Book
books.author: Heather Christle
books.notes: I loved this book. I got it because I was depressed and looking for good books on depresssion. I also got, from the library at the same time, 'Furiously Happy', which was cute but I didn't exactly dig its humor (and its a humor book). Anyway, I'd been eyeing 'The Crying Book' for a while now; it popped up all over the place, even before I got depressed, but finally I got it. It's a bit like prose poetry, or maybe a lyric essay; a series of fragments about crying and her experiences and what it means to be depressed. A mix of science-y things, folklore, traditions, etc. around crying with her personal experience, her particular cries, how her husband deals with her crying, that kind of stuff. I really liked it. It didn't make me sad per se, which I guess I was worried about. It's not exactly a sad book, but it is about sadness.

books.title: Solecism
books.author: Rosebud Ben-Oni
books.notes: Okay, very late on writing my notes. It's not Nov 2021... Still. I read this because I had taken that class with Rosebud, and wanted her to review my manuscript for me. This is one of her earlier books -- I've been meaning to read her more recent stuff -- and honestly many months later I don't remember too much other than I liked it, it felt very controlled and powerful. Sometimes poetry just feels... strong, or rich, or ... well-cut, like an athlete's body. Weird metaphor, but still. That's how I felt about this book. I don't think it was amazing, but it was firm, clean. I should read her newer stuff. I have read some poems here and there in magazines, but I should read the books.

books.title: Pachinko
books.author: Min Jin Lee
books.notes:
I read this on the way to Sydney, and I think I finished it during quarantine. I picked it up in a free public library in Cambridge, I think on one of my morning walks with Sara, and then it sat on my bookshelf for a while. I'd seen it around but honestly I didn't know what it was about. Then I read it on the way to Sydney.

It was very, very good. It followed a multigenerational Korean family that spends several generations in Japan during Japanese occupation of Korea and then through WWII. I knew Japan occuped Korea, but I didn't appreciate that even Koreans who had lived in Japan for multiple generations were not granted full rights and were treated so poorly. I guess it's not too surprising -- very similar in the US -- but I just didn't know all that history.

The characters were really interesting, and it was especially amazing to see the grandmother character -- who is a child at the beginning -- live through so many different kinds of lives. Running a small seaside inn for sailors, living a normal-ish life in Japan, selling kimchi during the war, her children becoming somewhat wealthy, watching her grandchildren deal with racism in high school... that woman saw so much, lived so many different kinds of lives.

books.title: No One is Talking About This
books.author: Patricia Lockwood
books.notes: Another quarantine read. Weird book but I liked it a lot. Had some 'Agua Viva' vibes at the beginning, but if Agua Viva were about the internet. Kind of listless and fragmented views of contemporary society, and then at some point the narrator's sister has a baby that has severe problems and will likely die young. Then it's so different, and the narrator is so focused on the baby and its joys (I wanted to write 'little joys' but are they little?) and that's what no one is talking about -- this very real thing of a short life and what it means to focus on it.

books.title: What Alice Forgot
books.author: Liane Moriarty
books.notes: Listened to this during quarantine when I'd pace the room for exercise. Loved it. About a mother who loses 10 years of her memory and deals with her life as a soccer mom of three about to divorce her husband -- and she's back pregnant with their first child and super happy. It's a nice little exercise on how people change, and what that means and who we become and why we become that way. There's a lot of 'why am I like this?' and when her memory finally comes back it all makes sense. Experiences made her that way. But she's able to incorporate a bit of her old self into her current self, and figure out how to move forward.

books.title: Big Little Lies
books.author: Liane Moriarty
books.notes: Another quarantine listen, though I might have finished this one after quarantine; I think I started it right before I left so actually I listened to most of it on runs around Mosman. Also great, murder mystery, mostly about a woman sexually assaulted who gets pregnant from the assault and ends up moving to the town her rapist lives in in a vague hope of meeting him again. Five years later. So it's about these preppy moms and their fights and their secrets. It's about the woman being stuck on the assault, and another woman whos husband abuses her but she can't quite leave, and it turns out the abuser was also the rapist. And then there's kid drama, etc. Fun, interesting read.

books.title: Eucalyptus
books.author: Murray Bail
books.notes: Got this at Kinokuniya in Sydney. I remembered reading it as a kid but didn't remember anything about it -- except maybe a woman wandering through a eucalyptus forest with a man. So I read it again. I really liked it. It's about a guy who moves out to the country and ends up planting one of each eucalyptus species on his property. He has a daughter and says whoever can correctly identify each tree can marry her. She hates the idea, and ends up meeting this kind of vagabond in the bush who tells stories about each of the trees. He's slowly identifying them, in his own way, but not really to win her, just because he knows it and wants to tell her stories. His competition is man from Adelaide who knows a lot about eucalyptus -- he's walking around with the father, slowly identifiying them all. Funnily enough I forget how it ends -- I think she ends up with the vagabond, and there's some reason he's there, he's been hired to plant the trees or maintain the fences or something, or maybe he makes the nameplates for the trees? Anyway, obviously I should read it again! But mostly I liked learning about the different eucalyptus, and the almost fairytale story, and it had a bit of Unbearable Lightness vibe in that the narrator kept talking about stories and what they mean and can do.

books.title: Station Eleven
books.author: Emily St John Mandel
books.notes: Picked this up from Caitlin when we were visiting them on our crazy roadtrip. She said it was good, and I read it in a rush -- while we were driving? Honestly I don't remember. Anyway, the book is about a future where there's a pandemic (lol) that kills 99% of all people. So it's about a future where most people now live in small, rural communities. No electricity, etc. Very interesting in terms of imagining what the world looks like when most people die. Also had the backstory of characters, and had nice tie-ins with different characters having connections from 'before'. I thought the ending was just the right amount of perfect fit. Not so perfect it feels cheesy, but perfect enough to make the book fun. I could go on about other details -- it mostly follows a traveling theatre, and the book starts with a famous actor having a heart attack on stage right before the pandemic hits. There's a comic book, created by the famous actor's ex-wife, and it gets into the hands of some of the main characters in the after times (there was just a tiny number made, she wasn't really interested in getting it published) but they have no idea where it's from or who the author is. There's an airport where there's a small community of people who got grounded there during the pandemic and never left. One guy starts a museum, and interviews people who comes by. The main 'bad guy' is a cult-like leader that leads a vicious gang. It was good.

books.title: Sorry and Beyond
books.author: Brian Butler and John Bond
books.notes: I picked this up at that bookstore in Australia, the one we went to with Ann and Annalisa and Stephen and my parents after we stayed at the Sidley house. I read it slowly, starting it in Sydney and probably finishing it sometime when I was back in the States. It was good, documenting the history of the Stolen Generation, and what it took for the Australian government to apologize. John Howard refused to accept any responsibility, and thus saw nothing to apologize for. In fact, he maintained his entire time as PM that the government had done nothing wrong, despite all the evidence to the contrary -- even evidence produced by a government investigation. It was Kevin Rudd, Howard's successor, who apologized, long after the states had and the people effectively had.

books.title: Your House Will Pay
books.author: Steph Cha
books.notes: I saw Steph Cha give a talk at Tin House, and then got interested in her book, a crime fiction account of the aftermath a generation past the murder of Latasha Harlins by the Korean cornerstore owner that contributed to the Rodney King riots. It was a great, interesting book, that imagined Latasha Harlin's family's life after her murder, as well as the life of Soon Ja Du's children. (Though Cha fictionalizes these characters, she discusses all the research she did into the real murder, as well as the riots and the changing demographics of LA over the subsequent 30 years.) Soon Ja Du's younger daughter, born after the murder, doesn't know about her mother's history, who changed her name and starts a new life elsewhere in LA. The spark for the novel is someone shoots her mother in revenge, and the daughter learns about the history (her older sister knows, and that explains the tension in the family) and deals with her mother being close to death as well as the knowledge of her path. The crime fiction aspect is who attempted the murder of the Soon Ja Du character, but the playing out of her backstory, and the Latasha Harlins' brothers life, is what really makes the book interesting.

books.title: Mind in Motion
books.author: Barbara Tversky
books.notes:
Had Google buy this for me at the start of my internship there. I ended up reading a bunch of her papers by the time the book got to me (because Silas and I were roadtripping and so I couldn't get it til I got back to NY) so it wasn't as exciting as I had hoped. I also think I just read the parts relevant to the internship, because I wanted to summarize it for a lit review I was doing for them.

Anyway, I would say a big thrust of the book that I got (that was relevant to my internship) was that people are physical beings and so our tools are tool. Paper, for instance, has edges and thus also has centrality. Across cultures, things that are centered are more important. It felt a bit like 'Metaphors We Live By' in that way -- trying to get at the embodied reasoning behind human behavior. So she'd do experiments having kids and adults order stuff, and see how they laid out the ordering to learn what the physicality of ordering meant.

books.title: Fishwork
books.author: Caitlin Maling
books.notes: Got this book at Kinokuniya in Sydney, because I wanted to get some Australian poetry books. I just kept picking random books based on title and look and feel, and this is one that spoke to me. The author spent time on a research vessel on the great barrier reef, and the collection is about/in response to that. I liked them, a simple straightforward style, lots about fish, about researchers, about her being away from her family, about being a poet on a science vessel.

books.title: Lemons in the Chicken Wire
books.author: Alison Whittaker
books.notes: Similar to above, or rather, I got this at the same time as Fishwork, from Kinokuniya in Sydney (the QVB? the CBD? something around there) because I wanted some Australian poetry. While Fishwork was about fish research (kind of -- I mean all poetry isn't really about anything) this was more of an identity book. The poet is lesbian and aboriginal, so it was a lot of that and I seem to recall some more erotic stuff. It was a bit... hm, more cutting than Fishwork? Just different. The vibe, that I'm recalling many months later (vibe is a word I've been using a lot these days), was more active... hm. What do I mean. Whereas Fishwork felt a bit like describing, Lemons in the Chicken Wire felt a bit more like experiencing. Maybe.

books.title: A Year Without a Name
books.author: Cyrus Dunham
books.notes:
I finally picked this up when I found it at Books are Magic after I moved to Brooklyn. I'd been meaning to get it since I heard Cyrus talk at Tin House, and even actively tried to find it when I was at Powell's in Portland, though I didn't remember the name only the author and maybe some versions of the book have the name differently? Anyway, I finally got it and read it.

I really liked it. It's about their decision to transition to male, and the fraughtness of it, and their relationships as they go through this, and I remember this particular theme of not wanting to give up womanhood as an oppressive identity -- or rather maybe not wanting to take on the male identity which is tied into being the oppressor. Because he was in so many queer/lesbian spaces. Also I think he highlighted a lot of the uncertainty that can be part of transitioning -- there's a foreword that addresses this, and how he wanted or rather thinks it's fine/important to portray transitioning as messy, even if it's not politically more effective.

books.title: Eunoia
books.author: Christian Bök
books.notes:
Picked this up at Powell's. Amazing I hadn't read it yet. I read some random portions out loud to Caitlin and Josh and it sounded like gibberish but when I actually sat down to read it it made a decent amount of sense, if it did ramble a bit.

(This is the book where each chapter only uses a single vowel.)

In the notes he discusses the rules he had for himself for each chapter, like wanting to use a large variety of words, and each chapter had to have someone sailing a boat and a fight scene and a sex scene, stuff like that (I don't remember exactly). Basically making it really hard. And it was fun to read, it was impressive but it was also fun.

books.title: The Reef
books.author: Iain McCalman
books.notes: Picked this up at a little free public library in Cambridge. I was thrilled to pick it up -- I think I'd just got back from Sydney? Anyway, it was an interesting book, kind of six vignettes about the great barrier reef, each focused on a person or story, many old and about the travesties performed on the aborigines who lived on or near the reef. But also some fun stuff about the history of discovery and science of the reef, early colonial navigators who saw it mostly as a problem for trade and traffic, or as something to be explored. Our current sense of it being a place of great biodiversity is very modern.

books.title: IRL
books.author: Tommy Pico
books.notes: Did I pick this up used and then finally read it ages later? I don't remember. When did I read this? This is why I must take notes. :S:S:S

books.title: The Undressing
books.author: Li-Young Lee
books.notes: Ok I recall this one slightly more. I might have gotten this... from the library? But why? I liked the book. It had real magic, almost religious. The first poem has this image of the speaker kissing a woman's body, while she describes something ... religious. Or rather, maybe it was a book of truths. It had a heaviness to it. The woman's words were heavy.

books.title: The Sixth Extinction
books.author: Elizabeth Kolbert
books.notes:
Picked this up at the Carroll Gardens Brooklyn Public Library, my new public library after I moved to Brooklyn. I'd seen it around but didn't realize it had won some big award. It was very good, very interesting, each chapter looking at some other aspect of extinction, framed through a single animal gone extinct. She started with the invention/discovery of the very idea of extinction. It's not obvious that there might have been animals on earth that are no longer here. But as we found more bones, we realized some of them must belong to animals we've never seen before. Other chapters talked about fossil records as ways of dating the history of the planet. And others talked about modern extinction, a result of global travel that introduces animals and fungi and bacteria into ecosystems that never had to deal with that before.

A big theme I remember is that there have been many large extinctions in the past, and the study of those basically says that what made a species successful in the past doesn't really predict its success during an extinction event, because the climate radically changes. And I wanted to hear the author's opinion our current mass extinction, and if it should be viewed differently the past ones. But she never really weighs in on that, and so I felt the ending a bit lackluster, like she didn't take a side or present an opinion or argument. But she has written another book, so perhaps it's in there. Or maybe she doesn't want to take a perspective, and wants to leave it to the reader. But I wanted her to tell me what she thought.

books.title: Colorful
books.author: Eto Mori
books.notes: Read this for the computer science book club. Short book, easy read. Maybe a YA book? Translated from Japanese, so hard to tell. Anyway, I really liked it. About a soul that gets a second chance in a 'homestay' body of a kid (14 year old) who commited suicide but is brought back to life (by god?) and this soul has to figure out his shit. So the book is about the soul realizing all the ways the kid misinterpreted his life. It was a nice conceit and I felt really well done.

books.title: How Will You Measure Your Life?
books.author: Clayton M. Christensen, James Allworth, and Karen Dillon
books.notes:
I really liked the beginning of the book. It was recommended to me by Madison Le at Google, and it's a Harvard Business School professor basically summarizing his business research and applying it to your life choices. The first chapter is about 'hygiene' versus 'motivation' in jobs -- being paid enough is hygiene, but after a certain amount it's not actually a motivator. But the rest was more analogical, and trying to apply business research to raising kids and such. That's fine, I didn't think it was wrong per se, I just got bored and didn't really want to take life advice from an HBS prof trying to pass off his life wisdom.

He has a bit about taking 'emergent' opportunities versus planning your career. Okay, sure. There was an interesting thing about what 'job' something does. He talks about research on how a store improves their milkshake. So instead of asking customers what they life in a milkshake, they ask what purpose does the milkshake serve. So if one person comes in and is getting a milkshake to drink during their morning commute, that's different than a parent getting their kid a milkshake as a treat. It's less about demographics and preferences than what role it's filling. Then he tries to make this relationship advice, like what role or 'job' are you doing for your partner. Kind of interesting.

But that's about when I got bored and starting skimming. He has a thing about not 'outsourcing' raising your kids, and that early experiences are really important and later ones mostly just follow from the early ones. Again, sure, but this guy doesn't study children he studies businesses. He has a thing about how your family needs to create a culture -- again, business culture being his actual research. I just felt like he started overstretching his field of expertise. Also, there's all this research on habits and nudging that is actually about this stuff that I've read.

The epilogue seemed super religious, so I skipped it. At that point I was hardly reading anyway. Still, I got something out of it.

books.title: Life on Mars
books.author: Tracy K. Smith
books.notes:
Bought this ages ago -- maybe at Book Culture? Don't remember anymore, sigh. I think this was one of the books I took to Sydney for quarantine but didn't end up reading, and I lugged it back to the U.S. and drove it halfway across the country because I'm that committed to always having options.

I finally actually read it in NY, mostly on the subway to and from Columbia from my new apartment in Brooklyn. I loved it. Wow. This is the first stuff I've really read by Tracy K. Smith, maybe I read one of her poems in Rosebud's class but this is the first book, after having seen her books everywhere and the whole poet laurate of the us, and even hearing her on the New Yorker's poetry podcast.

At this point the details of the book are fading slightly. Her father is a scientist (maybe her mother too?). (I'd flip through the book but I'm in Cambridge and I'm pretty sure it's in NY.) The book is definitely about science, or science and astronomy is a theme, but I just remember almost every poem being so biting, so perfect. I don't remember it being formally very playful or anything, but that makes it even better -- that she was able to do so much with just the standard idea of a contemporary poem. Maybe I'm forgetting some unique details, but generally I just recall being stunned by it. I recently read another of her books -- Wade in the Water -- which hopefully I'll document before I forget it all...

books.title: The Art of Raising a Puppy
books.author: The Monks of New Skete
books.notes:
Caitlin let me take this from their bookshelf when we were there for her wedding, because that's when I got Topo. It's funny that the authors are monks, or I thought that was funny. It's a monastery in upstate NY where they also breed German Shepherds.

The book is good. I read it all the way through, skipping I think just some more memoir-esque sections at the end. The book starts with following a pregnant dog through giving birth, and then follows the puppies into adulthood. It's a mix of information about dogs and advice on how to train them. I liked it, I felt it gave me a lot of context.

I was also watching a ton of youtube videos, and eventually the information started to feel a bit repetitive or slow, and there were a few parts that felt... not out dated but kind of irrelevant, like this section on electric collars which I guess were gaining in popularity at the time.

books.title: Dawn
books.author: Octavia Butler
books.notes:
I read this for Alan's Brambleberry book club that eventually didn't actually happen. Also apparently it's published sometimes as part of a longer book that includes the first three books in this series. Then it's called 'Lilith's Brood'. Anyway. I got it from the Carroll Gardens Brooklyn Library.

I really liked it. Very interesting ideas. You follow Lilith, who's been held in some kind of alien cell since Earth had fallen apart. I'm forgetting exactly why Earth is fucked, but most humans die (war?) and the aliens come and rescue the remaining ones. The aliens have this thing where they genetically combine with other species they rescue, sharing abilities, and this freaks out Lilith who doesn't want to be bred. But Lilith is being prepared to take a group of humans back to earth to repopulate it. She gets embedded in an alien family, and they even give her some of their genetic powers. Then she 'wakes up' a group of humans and tries to convince and prepare them to go back to earth. This is where it felt a bit like Parable of the Sower, lots of humans trying to figure out how to cooperate outside of any safety and security. Eventually they get to go back to earth (so say the aliens) but I think at the end Lilith doesn't get to go. But the cliffhanger is that's she's pregnant with a guy from the group (who ended up getting murdered by someone else in the group) but the baby with be a new alien-modified baby.

books.title: Field Theories
books.author: Samiya Bashir
books.notes: Picked this up somewhat at random from Powell's bookstore when Silas and I passed through on our LA to Seattle roadtrip. I just liked the title and cover and first few poems. I think I thought the author was a male (based on the cover) but realized halfway through looking at the author bio it's a woman. I liked it, though it mostly used physics as a theme or metaphor, rather than a real subject matter.

books.title: Personal Science
books.author: Lillian-Yvonne Bertram
books.notes: I must have ordered this on Bookshop.org, maybe from Grolier's during the pandemic. I'd been meaning to read more of Lillian-Yvonne's work after getting into Travesty Generator. I really liked Personal Science. There's a long poem in the middle, I'm forgetting its name, that deals with weather patterns and climate change.

books.title: Love in the Big City
books.author: Sang Young Park
books.notes:
Translated by Anton Hur.

I loved it. It had a very breathless vibe, maybe Tommy Pico-esque but obviously different. Follows a gay Korean man through college and a bit beyond, his friend and their drinking and sleeping around, his journey into being a writer, a man he dates for a while that can't accept being gay, a long-term boyfriend that is stable but they eventually split up so the boyfriend can go work (in China, I think). The main character doesn't go because he has AIDS. I can't really think of another novel quite like it. I also loved the structure. I like the kind of almost-not-completely one story vibe. It was like four different novels, where each one is probably the same narrator but not quite.

books.title: Summary of Small Things
books.author: Carol Adams
books.notes: Picked this up in... somewhere in Australia, not Sydney, maybe Darwin at a market? Kind of a long prose poem, or maybe just a journal. She lives in Alice Springs, talks a lot about the weather and gardening and her painting. It was peaceful, I appreciated it was a piece of art by someone not too famous, that gave it a special hue, made it easy, nice, made me feel good. It reminded me of being a teenager and just appreciating writing, sending emotional emails and saying, See, even this is Writing, this is Art, this is beautiful because words that I write are often beautiful in their everyday way.

books.title: The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailer
books.author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez
books.notes: Picked this up at the online Harvard Bookstore Warehouse Sale, I believe... I think just because it was Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and the title sounded nice. I ended up reading it when in LA with Tani and Danny and my parents and Kristin for Tani's 40th birthday, Tani's first international travel since COVID started. It turns out this is actually a journalistic account of a story of a shipwrecked sailor, which had some political meaning at the time as he was giving a false story in order to make the government seem better... something about how the ship was carrying too much or maybe illegal cargo... anyway, the sailor had a pretty incredible story of surviving after falling off a ship traveling from Alabama to Colombia, on a life raft and drifting at sea for eleven days.

books.title: the black maria
books.author: Aracelis Girmay
books.notes:
Hm, how long had I been meaning to read this? I bought it at some bookstore in downtown Boston I'd never been to before, I believe after Rich and Alan and maybe Rodrigo and I had gone to get burgers at Chloe's after we had tried to go visit the pet adoption place but had been turned away because it was too late in the day or maybe there were no appointments. After burgers we walked around Newbury St a bit and went into this nice bookstore that I had never been to. They had 'the black maria' so I bought it.

The book itself is amazing. Girmay has a series of poems called 'to the sea', which made me think of my own series 'dear ocean', and the similarities and differences between these titles. 'the black maria' is a term for the ocean, or maybe a ship, I'm forgetting. Girmay is pretty historical in this book, in fact it reminded me a bit of The Deaf Republic in having characters and definitions and this kind of external structure to the poems.

I lent the book to Kathy, but I think I need to read it again. Girmay is dealing with slave trade, and the crossing of the oceans, and immigration, and history, and also just the sea and its blackness.

books.title: Wade in the Water
books.author: Tracy K. Smith
books.notes: When did I buy this? Maybe at Book Culture, because I saw it on sale. But maybe I'm just rememberign seeing this book there, and thinking I should read it because I hadn't read anything by Tracy K. Smith. Anyway, when I finally read it (when?) I loved it. A book more about blackness than Life on Mars, I remember enjoying it thoroughly, being impressed by Smith's ability to point, to move me, though I'm not really remembering any details. Sigh.

books.title: Gathering the Tribes
books.author: Carolyn Forché
books.notes: Got this from the Brooklyn Public Library (I think...) hardcover. Forché's first book, I think, and the description of the book, or introduction (I think it won some prize) helped me navigate the book, which documented her time living with a native American couple, and also her eastern European grandmother, and also lesbianness? (I don't think queerness has come up again in what I've read of her...) The poems have a kind on old, intense there-ness, that kind of still description I associate with an older generation of poets, like Mary Oliver, rather than the move shifting almost surrealism of contemporary poetry.

books.title: Hope in the Dark
books.author: Rebecca Solnit
books.notes:
Why did I get this? Was it  at the Harvard Bookstore Warehouse Sale? Maybe. I know I've been meaning to read something by Rebecca Solnit.

I really liked this book. She wrote it shortly after Bush won a second term (I think) but she rereleased in 2016. The basic tenet of the book is that liberals have reason to hope, and in fact despair is a way of giving up, because hope necessitates/motivates action. But she goes into a lot of detail about various political situations which I didn't have enough context for to know if they were reasonale. Like she'd say this bad thing happened in the US (some law getting repealed or struct down by the supreme court or a war or something) but there was also a big gain in a Latin American country. So I wasn't sure I really believed/followed all of that.

But her articulation of how despair is a form of giving up really stuck with me. The title is from a Virginia Woolf quote about how the future is dark-- but by 'dark' she means 'obscured' or 'uncertain', not bad, and that dark is the best we can hope for for the future: to not be known or set in stone, but for there to be a chance for change. So the title is about being hopefully in the uncertainty of the future. Which I think to Solnit really means to act in the fact of an uncerain future. 'Hope is not a lottery ticket you can sit on the sofa and clutch, feeling lucky. It is an axe you break down doors with in an emergency.'

'Hope locates itself in the premises that we don’t know what will happen and that in the spaciousness of uncertainty is room to act. When you recognize uncertainty, you recognize that you may be able to influence the outcomes–you alone or you in concert with a few dozen or several million others. Hope is an embrace of the unknown and knowable, a alternative to the certainty of both optimists and pessimists. Optimists think it will all be fine without our involvement; pessimists take the opposite position; both excuse themselves from acting. It’s the belief that what we do matters even though how and when it may matter, who and what is may impact, are not things we can know beforehand. We may not, in fact, know them afterward either, but they matter all the same, and history is full of people whose influence was most powerful after they were gone.'

'Your opponents would love you to believe that it's hopeless, that you have no power, that there's no reason to act, that you can't win. Hope is a gift you don't have to surrender, a power you don't have to throw away.'

So she views hope as a kind of power that mustn't be given over to despair. Despire, to Solnit, is the worst. She talks about people despairing over a piece of climate legislation that passed-- that it's not enough, that it won't help. She says the people who worked on the legislation know it is not enough but are hopeful for more; uninvolved people tend to be the ones that criticize, and they are coming from a place of despair, that nothing will ever be enough.

She also has this idea that even in a loss, like an act that does not seem to cause the change we hope, there is sometimes a seed planted that grows something greater. So even if you lose a legislative battle, you may have started to shift people's attitudes that will allow you to win a bigger battle later. 'Cause-and-effect assumes history marches forward, but history is not an army. It is a crab scuttling sideways, a drip of soft water wearing away stone, an earthquake breaking centuries of tension. Sometimes one person inspires a movement, or her words do decades later, sometimes a few passionate people change the world; sometimes they start a mass movement and millions do; sometimes those millions are stirred by the same outrage or the same ideal, and change comes upon us like a change of weather.'

She also talks a lot about joy, and the importance of joy in activism. 'Joy doesn’t betray but sustains activism. And when you face a politics that aspires to make you fearful, alienated, and isolated, joy is a fine initial act of insurrection.' 

'Despair demands less of us, it’s more predictable, and in a sad way safer. Authentic hope requires clarity—seeing the troubles in this world—and imagination, seeing what might lie beyond these situations that are perhaps not inevitable and immutable'

books.title: blue hour
books.author: Carolyn Forché
books.notes: Another book from the Brooklyn Public Library. The blue hour is the hour just before the sun rises, when the world turns blue. I think it is a French idiom, and the book I think (ugh I can't quite remember) is partly chronicling her experience in the morning with her child, and she is in France. Ugh, perhaps there is a long poem called the blue hour, yes, an abcederian, I remember telling Kathy about it, and in the notes Forché discusses reading a kind of hymnal litany of someone's life, an autobiographical poem that she thought at the time she could never mimic. But here she does it, an abcederian hymnal litany.

books.title: Oculus
books.author: Sally Wen Mao
books.notes:
I think I got this at the Harvard Bookstore Warehouse Sale around my birthday. Because of covid it was virtual again, which isn't as fun but still fun. I just liked the look of the cover, and I guess the description. I read it mostly in Boston over the holidays. It's got themes of Asian American exclusion/exoticization as well as technology, similar to some of Franny Choi's stuff about the techno-eroticism of asian-looking people. But it was also very historical, and centered in NYC.

There are a series of poems about Anna May Wong, an early Chinese actress and the roles she was given and the yellow-face white actors took part in. There are lots of poems that respond to Asian Americans from the past. The last poem is about seeing Anna May Wong's face all over ads in NYC (the ad is for an exhibition about Asian exclusion/inclusion) and how the speaker recognizing Wong's face makes her feel at home, no longer a stranger.

I think I liked this book because it had strong themes. It was a book where the notes and context are really helpful, and sometimes that bothers me, but I liked that she kept coming back to similar ideas (but with different characters?) over and over again.

books.title: The Secret to Superhuman Strength
books.author: Alison Bechdel
books.notes:
Brad got this for me for christmas. I didn't even know Alison Bechdel had a new book. I've actually never read her other ones, though I did see the musical adaptation of Fun Home with Ann and Dad (and someone else?) in Sydney and loved it. The book is kind of a memoir about her life through the lens of different fitness crazes she's been through, but it's also about her anxiety and drinking and relationships and attempt to find inner peace. It's woven in with history about the transcendentalists, Coleridge and Wordsworth and Margaret Fuller, as well as Jack Kerouac and another woman, and Adrienne Rich. You get to experience her success with Fun Home, her mother's death, and it takes us all the way through the pandemic.

It's interesting. Brad said she's a good person to spend time with, and the book feels essentially like that -- spending some time in Bechdel's mind, as she tries to tie some threads together about her life, or rather follow some threads through her life. Again, fitness is the central theme, but so is trying to find peace. She's a neurotic work-aholic, and fitness seems to fit into this. But fitness is also true and good, and I think that's an interesting struggle, and she ties it into her experiences of bliss, which tend to come from fitness (though have also come from mushrooms). These moments of bliss are like touchstones of the book, and she's always tryign to get them back and understand where they came from.

What did I get out this book? There's something peaceful and nice about following someone through their maybe-too-self-aware journey of trying to find meaning and peace in their life, and having a good gut feeling that they'll get there (which she does). It's almost like better than self-help, to spend time with someone you feel some kind of connection to, similarity to, and getting to see how they did it. Because then maybe I can do it too.

books.title: The House on Mango Street
books.author: Sandra Cisneros
books.notes:
Read this entirely while waiting for my flight to Charlotte to take off. I picked it up ages at my parents house, ironically, and then threw it in my bag because it was a short, fiction book on my too-read pile. Then my flight kept getting delayed and delayed, and I finished it shortly after we took off.

I was interested in this book because I feel I had heard of it before, I think it's kind of a classic, and I think it's mentioned in Meander, Spiral, Explode, the nonfiction book I read about different narrative structures.

It's a book of fragments, or short vignettes, told from the perspective of Esmeralda, a young kid in America (some unstated town) from Mexico. The theme is her wanting a nicer house, but the one they have is on Mango Street. It chronicles her friends, and the neighbors that come in and out of her life. I'd guess she's around eight years old at the beginning, maybe a young teenager at the end. It does that nice thing where the narrator doesn't understand everything, or understands it in their own special childhood way. At one point she gets her fortune told, asking about what house she'll live in and is told 'a home in the heart' which upsets her. She has an older friend who gets married young (before the 8th grade) and goes off to live with her husband because she wants to get out, but the husband is another kind of cage. She experiences sexual assault, in a way she doesn't (can't won't) describe. One day the kids make fun of a nice old lady who is bedridden and blind and that day the lady dies. A neighborhood kid let's them all ride in his nice car until the cops come and he kicks everyone out and crashes the car trying to escape from the cops.

It was very good. The writing was poetic, rich, it makes sense that Cisneros' has also written poetry. The book does have a cool narrative structure, no strict plot but the narrator is growing up, and the house is a artefact: something constantly circled around.

books.title: What You Have Heard is True
books.author: Carolyn Forché
books.notes:
This was part of my Carolyn Forché binge, and it's her memoir about spending time in El Salvador prior to the civil war in the 1980s. She had spent some time in Spain translating the poetry of a Salvadorian poet, and then that person's cousin (or something) kind of randomly approached her when she was living in California, asking her to go with him to El Salvador to learn and document what was going on there. She went with him on several trips, visiting the campesinos, which I think are kind of like slums, but also meeting with generals and people working at hospitals. The whole time, and she's young btw, like in her 20s I think, she's not sure why he brought her. She keeps saying, I'm a poet, why will a general want to speak to me? But being a poet, and also an American, held a lot of weight. And she got to -- well, that implies a privilege, and I think that's unclear -- witness a lot of what was going on while this guy -- his name was Leonel -- was trying to help, he wanted to help the people trying to rise up against the government, which was (and as far as I can tell still is) cruel and corrupt.

The book is well-written, engrossing, dragged a bit in the middle, the ending is fascinating, through her experience in El Salvador she works on a photo book about the country (writing to accompany the photos) and meets a war photographer who had also spent a lot of time in El Salvador. They end up getting together and eventually marrying and having a kid and occasionally hosting Salvadorians that are on the run or trying to navigate America. It's interesting to see how these experiences -- which are hers but also seem to not quite belong to her, because she's American and has not ancestory in the Americans, her grandparents were frm eastern Europe I think -- are central but also peripheral to the rest of her life, where she is an American poet. She doesn't become Salvadorian.

One of the best things about this book was the acknowledgements. She acknowledges my uncle, David! So crazy. Fr. David Ungerleider. I knew he has worked a lot in Mexico but I didn't know he had any connection to El Salvador.

books.title: Becoming Nicole
books.author: Amy Ellis Nutt
books.notes:
My mum has mentioned this book many times, as a great explanation of the trans experience, so I eventually when I was there last I found it on the bookshelf and picked it up. It follows a trans girl from rural Maine, who ended up being a part of an important civil rights case providing rights to transgender people. The main complaint was from I think her middle school, when a kid, clearly influenced by his grandfather, started bullying her and following her into the girls bathroom, saying if she can go (when she's 'actually a boy') then why can't he go into the girls bathroom too.

For me I think the most interesting thing was how easy it was for young children to accept her. They all just knew she was a girlboy, or a girl in a boy's body, or some other description that as five, seven, even ten years did not find strange at all. All this hate comes later, we pick it up from our parents (or grandparents) or other cultural things, but it seems like at our most basic we are totally accepting of anything.

The other thing that's interesting about Nicole is she is an identical twin, so it raises these interesting questions about the biological basis of transgenderism, because her brother isn't transgender.

books.title: Something I've Been Meaning to Tell You
books.author: Alice Munro
books.notes: I'd been reading these short stories before bed for many, many months. It stayed up in the loft at Brambleberry, and I'd dip into it from time to time. The book is worn out, so I probably found it at a little free public library or something. While the stories had no real connecting thread, the theme seemed to be women in rural Canada dealing with their mothers or sisters. In one story a woman is visiting her sister, whose child recently died in a car accident, and the sister is so put together and procedural the woman feels out of place, unsure how to support. In another, a young woman is visiting her grandparents who are constantly complaining about the woman's mother, who has some kind of degenerate disease and can't take care of the house to the grandmother's satisfaction. It's about the history these women come from, and how that history bears on them and their expectations and actions. They are wonderful, very rich stories with a lot of interiority to them. And it wasn't really til after I was done that I realized how unusual it must be have been for Munro to be writing so well and detailed and caringly about women, with very little violence or action to drive the stories.

books.title: The Sea Around Us
books.author: Rachel Carson
books.notes: I loved this so much that after I finished it I bought a used copy online. It took me a while to get through -- it's pretty dense, small words. Rachel Carson is a beautiful writer, describing every part of the ocean in a breathtaking way, just filled with these almost throw-away lines about how the continents used to be barren and desolate before plants moved to land from the sea, about how all life started in the ocean with all its nutrients and our blood harkens back to this time of being immersed in something life-giving. She talks about the accumulation of sediments, why the ocean is salty, the origins of life, valleys and mountains under the ocean. It's just infinitely inspiring. I want to read the modern version, and she wrote this in the 1950s I think, and even this 'updated' version is from the 1960s. Like she presents an idea that the Pacific Ocean (named, by the way, by Magellan for how 'passive' it was in contrast to the Atlantic, which is named after the lost city of Atlantis) was formed because the mass that flung from the earth to form the moon came from the Pacific. This is.. probably not true (though it turns out we're still not exactly sure how the moon was formed) but beautiful and engaging none the less, and she does say it's a theory and they don't know. Anyway, I hope to read it again, or at least dip into it, highlight my favorite passages, and just be with it more.

books.title: In the Lateness of the World
books.author: Carolyn Forché
books.notes: Where did I get this? I bought it somewhere. I feel this is towards the end of my Forché marathon. I think this is her most recent book. I liked it, and I liked seeing where it came from. It made a lot more sense. No one poem stuck out to me, though maybe it's because I'm 3 weeks late. Sigh.

books.title: 50 Queers who Changed the World
books.author: Dan Jones
books.notes: Bought this at the Harvard Bookstore Warehouse Sale. It's kind of a picture book, or coffee table book, but it's small, so maybe it's more of a gift book? Nice illustrations of the queers, and then a short one-page description of their life or work or activism. I liked it because I learned a lot, like about Christopher Isherwood whose memoir Goodbye to Berlin inspired the movie that inspired Cabaret. Or Patricia Highsmith, who wrote The Price of Salt which inspired the movie Carol. I liked learning about these early queer books that are really only recently being taken up in more popular culture. I want to read them. It was also just nice to learn about some other characters from history, and it's an easy book to flip through and return to. I read it in bed, before I would go to sleep.

books.title: Six Square Meters
books.author: Margaret Simons
books.notes: Picked this up at random when perusing the gardening section at the Cambridge public library. It's a short memoir-ish book about a woman's experience gardening. Not advice, just... stories or musing. And it turns out she's Australian! Talks about gardening in the Blue Mountains and then in the urban center of Sydney. It was fun, a kind of sarcastic or rather straight-talking look at gardening and life and things working and not and her not always knowing why and how some plants just work and others don't and some come back to life and others just don't. It was fun, I enjoyed spending some time with her mind and her garden.

books.title: How Dogs Think
books.author: Stanley Coren
books.notes: Book about research on dog psychology. Pretty interesting, pretty engaging. Some things I remember: breeds have different attributes, at a population level. The retrievers are easier to train, because they're all about focusing on the human; smell dogs are more distractable (good for scent work) but makes them harder to train. Dogs can count, to an extent. They're good at detecting motion, but can't do as well when things don't move. Their vision is better in some ways and worse than others. Their nostrils have places to collect scent; this is part of what makes them so good at smelling. What else... positive training is just easier to do. Negative training works, but it's trickier and more likely to go wrong (e.g. associate with the wrong action).

books.title: American Journal: Fifty Poems for Our Time
books.author: Tracy K. Smith
books.notes: Got this for free at the NYC Poetry Festival where I read with the Catapult crew. I finally dipped into it when I was in New York one time, reading it on the subway. I typically prefer reading books by a single poet. I feel it's hard to get into anthologies, it's too piecemeal for me, I can't really appreciate the poems. But I actually really liked this one. It was like a 'classic hits' book, and made me want to go get the books of the poets I hadn't read much of yet.

books.title: The Vanishing Half
books.author: Brit Bennett
books.notes:
Been meaning to read this for a while. I feel it was popping around my circles during the BLM protests, when I was looking for engaging reads because I found reading so far. But for some reason I never got to it. Then I think talking to Hansa at some point and him saying he had read recently, and I'd just gotten back into ordering from the Cambridge public library (instead of the Brooklyn one) so I requested this and Detransition, Baby. They both came in at the same time and with surprisingly similar covers.

The Vanishing Half is about two twins, Desiree and Stella Vignes, light-skinned black girls in a middle of nowhere town in Louisiana called Mallard that's obsessed with being light-skinned. So they treat darker-skinned black people terribly, but they're also/still treated badly by white people. The girls' father is lynched in front of their eyes. When he doesn't die, the men go to the hospital and shoot him in the face. As teenagers the girls run away to New Orleans, and Stella ends up leaving her sister and passing as white, effectively for the rest of her life. Desiree does kind of the opposite---marries a very dark skinned guy and has a dark-skinned daughter, Jude. Stella marries a white guy and has a white-looking daughter Kennedy. The book follows this story, like Desiree getting beaten by her husband and eventually returning to Mallard with her daughter (who is treated like shit because she's so dark), working at the local diner for the next 20 years and taking care of her mother. Stella ends up in LA with a wealthy white husband and a kind of obnoxious daughter, and is pissed when a black family moves in across the street. At first she avoids them, and then ends up befriending the wife, and then eventually abandoning her again when the neighbors start whispering.

So there's the story of Stella and Desiree, and then there's the story of Jude and Kennedy. Jude happens upon Stella, and then Kennedy, in LA during undergrad, and every few years bothers Kennedy, trying to bring the lie of Stella to light, which eventually she does and Stella eventually (after many years) admits this to Kennedy.

Then there's this weird transgender storyline about Jude's boyfriend, Reese. Hansa and I discussed this a bit. It's a bit obnoxiuos; there's a weird part about how Reese 'passes' as a man that doesn't really make sense as a parallel, and the drag queens they hang out with in LA, and Reese's underground testoterone usage, and eventual top-surgery. It's not that the plotline was bad, it was just kind of random and I think if you're gonna take it on then you need to take it on. And the passing bit was weird. I think there was potential---like looking at why Jude never tells her mother than Reese is trans (and this is why they don't get married). But it kind of weirdly focused in the issues of transition itself, which didn't make any sense as a parallel because the whole thing with Stella passing as white is that she didn't actually need to change at all.

Anyway, I liked it, I read it quickly. It was a bit too neat and tidy, a bit too clean and clear, but I thought the parallels of the twins was nice, as was their mother's decent in Alzeimer's as a kind of reversion back to their childhood. It made me think I should read that book 'Passing' that was recently made into a movie.

books.title: Detransition, Baby
books.author: Torrey Peters
books.notes: I loved this book. I didn't realize it was about actual babies until I got into it. I didn't really know what detransitioning was about, why people did it. This book was great because its characters were flawed, and had 'flawed' views, but the book dug into these tensions in the queer and trans communities, it let the characters think what we don't say out loud, and the characters had flaws but were making their way through the world as good people, doing their best. I thought the connection between trans women and cis divorced women was interesting. All the meditations on motherhood were fascinating. When do you get to feel like a mother? When is desiring motherhood the default, and when do you have to explain yourself? What does it mean to raise a child together?

books.title: If You See Me, Don't Say Hi
books.author: Neel Patel
books.notes: I think I inherited this when Caitlin moved out of Bromfield, but it's an advanced readers copy so I'm not sure where she would have gotten it from. The stories are good-- engaging and provocative and kind of echo-y like short stories should be. But I started to tire of the pretty crappy characters, and their misogyny. I'm all for an antihero, or a flawed hero, or just real people being crumby in their real people ways, but about halfway through the book I tired of the characters not learning, being assholes without much redemption.

books.title: Men Explain Things to Me
books.author: Rebecca Solnit
books.notes:
I picked this up at Topo's Bookstore in Queens when I finally went there, with Rodrigo, and afterwards we walked an hour back to Brooklyn just chatting about whatever. Topo's Bookstore was really amazing. Small, but with a really eclectic selection, lots of fun and weird and dark and queer zines and little things of art and a good selection of used (and some new) books. Also coffee and some snacks. I found this on the shelf just to the right of the door when you enter. After reading Hope in the Dark I knew I would get this one, especially since it was a bit cheaper because it was used.

This one, with its starting anecdote about a man trying to explain her own book to her, deals with gender-based violence. It came out in 2014, and I feel like... hm, what, that I knew it all but also maybe had forgotten it. My personal experience with sexism is more about dropping out of careers, men treating women poorly, but the book pointed to the spectrum being a man being mean to a man killing, and how shouldn't ignore the path between them. Or rather, need to acknowledge the links. While the mass murders in America are shocking and related to all kinds of things like access to weapons, they are also almost exclusively perpetrated by men. (My feeling is also white men, but I'm not sure.) And so it's one of those things like, yea, terrorism is bad, but so is crossing the road. So is being near a man.

Which is not to say things are 'getting better', and she's already written the hope book so this isn't someone who's uninterested in what has changed. But she is interested in how it is sidelined foro ther issues (like with mass murder) and how it's so ingrained as to feeling a bit like the air we breath.

books.title: Água Viva
books.author: Clarice Lispector
books.notes:
Oof, this is a book that took me years to finish, I even took it to quarantine in Sydney thinking I'd finish it there. But I also never wanted to push it, and just took my time, reading a couple pages when I felt like it.

It's an amazing book, a series of fragments in which she attempts to describe the nowness of life and art, and how to get at that with words, and how writing can be like painting, a true attempt to transmit directly from her to me, and the failing of that, and the success of that. It's stunning and strange, unlike anything else, and while I want to reread it I also feel like it isn't a book to gorge but rather take in slowly, when the nowness is right.

books.title: Pilgrim Bell
books.author: Kaveh Akbar
books.notes: I felt these poems were harsher than his first book, more jagged around the edges, more interested in ugliness than beauty, though they are beautiful (I think there's a point where he says he can't help but want to make them beautiful) but I feel he pushed against beauty. They are, like his first book, deeply religious, though I feel they are more about America and empire than his first book. There are a series of poems called 'Pilgrim Bell' that use full stops throughout, like after every phrase and some every word, a kind of tolling of the poem, making it stilted and ringing. I feel like it's a lot more visually interesting than his first book, though I don't quite remember and I don't have it with me here in Vermont. He seems to be using more of the page, giving the words more space. It's less tightly wound. Not that it goes full experimental, and the voice is still distinctly his, the kind of collage of images making a gestalt that he does so well. But now he gives the collage space to breath, makes the links between them ... well gives us more space in the links between them. What does that do? It's the space between the bell tolls. Like the full stops in the Pilgrim Bell poems, the space acts as a marker of the beat.

books.title: Whereas
books.author: Layli Long Soldier
books.notes: Got this somewhere to read while I was at Vermont Studio Center. I had a bit of a hard time getting into it at first, I found it a bit angular and hard to parse, but then I read some reviews and learned about the second part of the book, which is a response to an official US apology for the genocide the government committed against indigenous people. And after the reviews and learning the context of the second part (which I got when I got there also) the book became so much more accessible for me, I started to understand what she was doing and it actually became, interestingly, much more moving and emotional and, like, interesting, because she's doing a lot of really interesting things, formally, and structurally, and I think those things only started to click for me when someone gave me an in.

books.title: Autobiography of Red
books.author: Anne Carson
books.notes:
Rebeccah was always recommending this to me, and Anne Carson is famous, so I bought it in preparation for Vermont Studio Center and read it while here. While here, Tessa and Natasha both sang its praises, so it had a lot of build up but it met the expectations. I had no idea what it was about, I thought it was poetry, and it is, though it's called 'a novel in verse' I'd say it leans a bit more towards prose than poetry if only in that it has consistent characters and a loose narrative arc.

The story follows Geryon, ('Red' from the title), a young boy/red and winged monster, who, in the Greek myth, is killed as one of Hercules tasks. But this Geryon lives in the contemporary world, with cigarettes and hockey matches and buses to school, meeting Herakles (Hercules), and the whole thing is just very strange and wonderful in its blending of the ancient myth and modern time. 

I was very disappointed the Herakles doesn't kill Geryon at the end, as in the myth. Instead Herakles is a love interest, and later they meet again in Argentina (or Brazil?) and Herakles is with someone else (a photographer?) and in the end they all go to a volcano in Bolivia. It's blurbed as 'whimsical and haunting, ... richly layered and deceptively simple' and I think that's accurate. It's a fun read that feels like it has depth but you needed plunge into it if you don't want to.

books.title: Climate Lyricism
books.author: Min Hyoung Song
books.notes: Loved this. A little academic, but generally quite readable. Kind of a whirlwind of critique/close reading of fiction and poetry and how it relates to climate change. He defines 'climate lyricism' as the reading of climate change in all literature, and the active attempt to write climate change into everything. The book is more about the former; I'm curious his thoughts on the latter. He also has this idea, at the beginning, that the best writing or activism about climate change should encourage us to participate more, rather than what most current work does which is make us want to sit it out. It didn't really follow up on this thought, but I loved the idea of action that encourages more action, and want to think about what this actually looks like, or what examples there are to exemplify it.

books.title: Good Bones
books.author: Maggie Smith
books.notes: Library book, because I had reached out to Maggie Smith to do a manuscript consult and wanted to read some of her work. She never got back to me, but I enjoyed reading this (and another of her books). She definitely works in the theme of joy, and this was a lot about her children and grappling with their future and childlike joy with the dark realities of the world. She has a distinctive style, I'd say mostly simple, realistic poems where she muses on something she sees or feels. Most poems are just one or two pages long, single stanza with medium length lines, and the book becomes a gestalt of her reflections. It definitely felt like a later book, in that she has figured out her style and is refining it, making it more and more into herself rather than moving through many different styles or modes. I feel strange about this, I suppose it can come from certainty, but I often wonder about my own style, what it is, and if it's any good, because sometimes it strays from the contemporary mode and that makes me insecure. (Anne Boyer would berate me for this-- don't care about the contemporary mode, that's about taste. Instead, get at beauty.) Still, it's scary to walk down a less trodden path and not get much feedback; it's easier to do the more normal thing?

books.title: Cenzontle
books.author: Marcelo Hernandez Castillo
books.notes: Picked this up at Topos Bookstore in Queens, on a whim. The book is formally interesting, that is the shape of the poems are wild and that's part of what attracted me to it, his commitment to using the whole page. The content of the book is immigration, Mexican refugees, queerness. Cenzontle is the word for mockingbird in Spanish. I don't remember many details of the book, mostly that I liked it, that his language was fresh and stark, and that he really avoided the singlestanzamediumlinelength, instead defaulting to caesura and white space.

books.title: The Color of Law
books.author: Richard Rothstein
books.notes: Got this from the library and read it while at Vermont Studio Centers. It documents government instatiation of American city segregation, making a constitutional argument that since such segregation is 'de jure' (of the law) rather than 'de facto' (people simply choosing to live in certain place) then the government has a responsibility to correct the negative outcomes for Black people. I liked that it was accessible, well-written, and in some ways a long list of examples of how the government ensured and sometimes even created segregation with government policy, often knowing that it was unconstitutional to do so.

books.title: Goldenrod
books.author: Maggie Smith
books.notes: Read this at Vermont Studio Centers. I liked it; Maggie Smith has a consistent style, kind of uplifting but honest personal poetry, tending toward a single page and medium length lines. Still, she does it very well, so it's a pleasure to read.

books.title: Are you my mother?
books.author: Alison Bechdel
books.notes: Oof, so good. I read it quickly, over a few days at Vermont Studio Center, often in the evenings. (Incl that evening I finished it in the dining room and then called my mum to discuss it, then heard weird noises and Rosalie coming out of the dark.) My therapist actually had mentioned it, and being at VSC and seeing it at the bookstore there led me to buy it and read it. I read this before Fun Home, so I ended up reading her graphic novels (well, memoirs) in the opposite order she published/wrote them. With Superhuman Strength I thought the constant self-reflection and dive into literary history was part of that book, but it was with Are You My Mother that I started to see that's just Bechdel's thing, as it bringing all that meta-thought into the book's content itself. The book talks about the book getting written, showing opening pages to her mother, it spirals her own readings of psychoanalysis theory from its founders while also going to therapy herself and forming attachments to her therapists. Her mother somehow lacked something she needed, and she ended up looking for that in everyone -- hence the title, a constant querying for a mother figure she maybe felt she never really had. I'd need to read it again to remember all the theory she pulls in, the particular researcher she kind of intellectually falls in love with, and his particular theories able childrearing. From a writers view, it's an interesting construction: meta while also narrative driven, trying to pull the best of both of those modes.

books.title: DICTEE
books.author: Theresa Hak Kyung Cha
books.notes: Another Vermont Studio Center read. Borrowed it from Sarah when I saw it in her studio during open studios in the middle of the residency. Obviously I knew about it previously through Jennifer, but now I finally read it. I think I was missing some mythological context for it, but I did appreciate it's wide-ranging span, it's prose poetry, it lack of allegience to a particular form or mode. Things like that I tend to just let wash over me, and I enjoyed this wash, this wade, if not feeling somewhat ignorant of exactly what it was trying to get at. Definitely about motherhood, girlhood, family, loss, immigration.

books.title: Dancing in Odessa
books.author: Ilya Kaminsky
books.notes: Another VSC read. Really good, not as good as Deaf Republic but nice to see the seeds for that book in this book. He has this whole omage to this Russion poet, and there's this line from that poet (sorry, forgot his name) about a student complaining that he wasn't getting published and the poet getting angry and saying 'Was Jesus published??'.

books.title: Crazy Rich Asians
books.author: Kevin Kwan
books.notes: Another VSC read, got it for $1 at the behind-the-church thrift. I really liked it! Is it a romance novel? I guess, though I'm not sure it read exactly like one. (Do we know they'll get together? Obviously I did, because I'd seen the movie.) I really liked the emphasis on class and all the distinctions based on class people made. That was the fabric that made the book interesting, to me. But I guess I was also reading for that given that zine I got once that was an essay about the movie v. book.

books.title: where bells begin
books.author: Tessa Micaela
books.notes: Another VSC read, this is Tessa's book (chosen by Jos Charles?), a meandering almost-novel in verse but too... mm detached from reality to really be a novel? Follows 'e' (I think?) through a town/city. Honestly don't remember too many details but also there aren't that many details? It's more a vibe.

books.title: The Country Between Us
books.author: Carolyn Forché
books.notes: I loved it! I'm writing this quite a while after reading it, but I read her memoir first and some of her later poetry, which I liked, but I think I liked this one a lot more; it feels a bit more raw, if I recall, a bit more 'in life' rather than reflecting on it. But perhaps I'm misremembering it.

books.title: To Make Room for the Sea
books.author: Adam Clay
books.notes: Read this I think at the Vermont Studio Center residency. I didn't like it that much; I just found it a bit bland and boring, but it won some poetry prize and was published by Milkweed, so I kept wondering what was so good about it and if someone where to show or teach  me the book if I would like it; what was I missing?

books.title: True Biz
books.author: Sarah Noviç
books.notes: Got this from the library. Fun, light-ish read about high schoolers at a Deaf school, and in particular a hard-of-hearing girl who's parents finally let her attend a Deaf school, and her quickly picking up Sign Language but also the drama of the other students and the principal who learns that the school will soon be shut down. The principal is a lesbian, and hearing but with Deaf parents, and there's a plotline about a kid from a well-known Deaf family who's parents have another kid who turns out to be hearing and how they all kind of are bummed about that and the dynamics of that whole thing.

books.title: Night
books.author: Etel Adnan
books.notes: Oh gosh I just don't remember anymore; this is why I need to take notes!

books.title: Ace
books.author: Angela Chen
books.notes: Loved it! Keep recommending it to others, though I'm not sure anyone has taken me up on it... Makes clear the diversity of asexuality, and how it sits in contrast against compulsory sexuality, and, though different, was a bit like 'Come As You Are' if only to validate the range of ways people can relate to each other and how we're all different and that's okay.

books.title: Human Dark with Sugar
books.author: Brenda Shaughnessy
books.notes: I think this was also a Raven buy... but maybe I'm actually mixing it up with finding it used at some other bookstore. I'd seen Shaughnessy's name around, since she came out with that book Octopus Museum (which I still haven't read). So I wanted to read some of her work. It was striking to me; sexy and bold without being too revealing or cringey. Sharp, colorful, rich language, is what I remember, strong lines, clear voice. How does one achieve that. She wrote poems in a way I've tried to write but hers come off as clever and rich while I feel mine would come off as deviant or too personal.

books.title: Customs
books.author: Solmaz Sharif
books.notes: Excellent. Is this my first Sharif book? I don't think it's her first, but I read this perhaps partially on a way to a conference? Don't remember where I bought it, but I remember the first poem, about natioanality and nationhood in the US, the experience of immigration, the violence of it. The poems, while somewhat narrative, felt very new, very unique, almost sharp but that's not quite it, I'd have to sit with them again to articulate it. It was a special book.

books.title: White Decimal
books.author: Jean Daive
books.notes: Picked this up randomly from... where? Book Culture? I don't remember. Still, it's a translation from French, and the poems were strange, ethereal, very much not the typical narrative style of contemporary poetry. I liked them, the way they washed over me, though I don't remember much of their content, I remember a sense of a well balanced page, lots of white, a nice kind of clean and clear vibe.

books.title: Teeth
books.author: Aracelis Girmay
books.notes: I think I eventually caved and got a used copy online from Alibris. I'd been looking for a used copy in bookstores and such and never found one. Taking these notes six months later, I don't remember too much about the poems. Sigh sigh sigh.

books.title: Viper Rum
books.author: Mary Karr
books.notes: I think this was also a Raven Bookstore find, though I don't quite remember. I had read one of Mary Karr's more recent books and enjoyed it, and I think I liked this one better, her tackling staying sober and religion and aging and death. I still haven't read her famous memoir, The Liar's Club (or something like that). I enjoy her poetry, but I'd need to spend more time with it to really feel its impact.

books.title: In a Lonely Place
books.author: Dorothy Hughes
books.notes: Another Alan novel that he recommended. Read this mostly on the train to IBM, I think my first week. I loved this book. Imagine American Pyscho but written by a woman who had actual empathy for her characters, and wanted to understand the perspective and mind of a man commiting such violence. Film noir, hard-boiled detective, following a guy who you learn is murdering women in LA, but befriends an old war friend who turns out to be a policeman on his case, and he revels in the cleverness of befriending the man who's out to get him. Eventually, though, of course, the policeman's wife figures it out, and traps him. It's a great look inside a deranged man, but also I felt some empathy, if only in the way emotions and moods can wash across the psyche, resulting in total miscontrual of reality, but it's this amazing portrait of how that works from the inside, how you can go from 'this is all great, i'm sure there are good reasons for this unexpected thing' to suddenly, 'everyone is conspiring against me and it is their fault'. Of course, most of us suffer this kind of thinking without hurting anyone as a result, so the empathy stops at some point, but the author's ability to let us access that kind of mind is amazing. Like American Psycho but good (and earlier!)

books.title: A Lost Land
books.author: Eavan Boland
books.notes: Honestly don't remember too much about this one (I'm writing these notes pretty late... maybe six months later... sorry sorry) but I believe I bought it used at Raven Bookstore and had been thinking of reading her work because she died somewhat recently and I saw a bunch of people talking about how wonderful she was and how great her writing was. Irish, ... pastoral? I guess it didn't leave too  much of an impression. I think I liked it? Sigh.

books.title: Another Brooklyn
books.author: Jacqueline Woodson
books.notes: Short book that I think I picked up from the little free public library on Western Ave; there were several new copies there I think. I liked it, following a group of four girls in Brooklyn and their years of being inseparable and then how they all end up later in life. It was good, and Woodson has a captivating, simple style---simple makes it sound bad, but really it's direct, clear, making something beautiful without being flowery or trying to sound too clever. Again, not sure how to describe this in a non-demeaning way. Anyway, if I recall, the book is kind of told in recollection, so it's also interesting from an information dispersal standpoint, as the narrator I think knows how the story will turn out but the reader only learns it piecemeal.

books.title: Stoner
books.author: John Willims
books.notes: Alan recommended this to me and I really liked it. Follows the like of Stoner, a farm boy sent to school to study agriculture to bring back better farming knowledge but ends up falling in love with English and becoming an English professor. His life is long and somewhat subdued; he doesn't enlist to go to war, he gets married to a woman who doesn't like him and they never share a bed or a room, they do manage to have a child the wife has little interest in until suddenly she kind of takes the child away from him, he is a decent english professor who writes (or almost writes?) an okay book on his area of study. It's kind of a question of if Stoner is just letting life happen to him, and if he should stand up for himself or his daughter or position (he runs afoul of a new dean, who makes his professional life hell), or if he is simply stoically bearing a hard life the best he came. It seems like it should be a boring book, but it's not, it's captivating and thought provoking and subtle.

books.title: Fun Home
books.author: Alison Bechdel
books.notes: Fun! Haha. I somewhat knew the plot because I had seen the musical version, but the book is good, similar to Are you my mother? in style, in that it's hyper self-reflective and steeped in study and analysis. And, like Are you my mother?, I'd like to read it again, because it felt deep and worth returning to.

books.title: Atlas of AI
books.author: Kate Crawford
books.notes: Eh, didn't like it that much. Super, super negative with little suggestion of what to do about any of the problems. Liked that it starts with metal and mining as the phsyical grounding of AI, and then moves up the ladder of abstraction to sentiment analysis and stuff, and I appreciated the context she brought to everything, like the basis of sentiment analysis in faulty psychology, but I just found it to be such a downer! And yes, things in life are bad, but to just document and make an 'atlas' of shit falling apart... I don't know. I read it as part of the IBM book club and others really liked it, because they felt like AI was so hyped in their life it was a nice counterpoint to that, but maybe I read more tech criticism and so didn't need someone just banging me over the head with its problems and not offering any positive way forward.

books.title: Nevada
books.author: Imogen Binnie
books.notes: Loved it. Read it because it was re-released, and the poet Stephanie Burt gave it a great write-up in the New Yorker, claiming it was the first book about and for trans people. Follows the main character through breaking up with her girlfriend and stealing her girlfriends car to do a cross-country drive, where she randomly meets a boy at a Best Buy and thinks he is probably trans (MtF) but just doesn't know it yet, and kind of tries to show him / draw it out of him, not like in a sexual way but more, as the author describes in the notes at the end, in a 'fairy godmother' way, but it never really works and he ends up going back to his girlfriend.
