Really interesting, with a kind of stuttering narrative style, but a super strong voice that really gets you in the head of this women.

books.title: Beach Read
books.author: Emily Henry
books.notes: It was fine. Meant to be a 'good' romance novel, and Caitlin and Kristin said the writing was really good, but I still found the characters stiff and the plot obnoxious and the gender politics, even though it's clear it was trying to be good about this, mildly offensive. (Emotionally stunted man must be 'seen' by a women who will accept him despite his problems. Like, yes, okay, you do have to accept people with their problems, but the sexism involved with assuming men can only secretively be emotional, and also must be emotionall broken in some way, is obnoxious.)

books.title: Confessions of a Shopaholic
books.author: Sophie Kinsella
books.notes: Read it on my phone using the Libby app. Fun, easy, but also insightful, a light way to get inside the mind of a true addict, and someone very much not entirely self-aware of their talents / abilities (and problems).

books.title: Algorithms of Oppression
books.author: Safiya Umoja Noble
books.notes: Really liked it. Thought it might be a bit outdated, because a lot of its examples are from several years ago when search engines and Google were quite different, but actually the criticism really holds up. Somewhat 'inspired' by Noble's experience googling things for her black nieces to do and getting mostly pornography, Noble takes a critical theory lens to search engines and outlines the problems when tech companies consider themselves and their products impartial and apolitical, despite there being no way to sort, organize, and prioritize information without being so. She also touches on library sciences and indexing practices as having similar problems to search engines, but search engines exasperate and repeat them, and can be more difficult to change as private companies are in control. (I feel I had a more nuanced and deeper appreciation of this book right after I read it; I'm probably six months out, which is why these notes might be a bit slim.)

books.title: The Alignment Problem
books.author: Brian Christian
books.notes: Listened to this on audible because mum recommended it and I was on an ethical AI reading kick over the summer. I was dubious at first, because the intro talks about AGI and alignment stuff, which I'm super not into, but it was actually pretty good and deep and wide. It talked about word embeddings, simple models for medical care, reinforcement learning, curiosity, and eventually got to safety and alignment issues at the end, mostly in toy cases but eventually getting to ethical altruism and William Macaskill, etc. etc. I don't really want to talk about that part too much, because I feel like it gets so much airtime and the issues of stuff like simple models that are explainable and the interesting interweave of reinforcement learning in CS and behavoiral shaping in psychology is much more interesting and relevant I think. I even think the toy problems with safety and alignment are interesting as they apply to real applications like self-driving and such; what's the best way to teach something? How do we avoid weird loopholes? What does it mean to embed values? (And we can think of values just as 'don't hit that object', doesn't have to be intense moral values.) Overall I found the book super well-researched, and quite deep. He had a whole part on the propublica breaking of the Compass recidivism software, and the resulting research on how you can't make all the fairness metrics work at the same time (I should really find the research on that part, it was super interesting), and how really decriminalizing a lot of stuff is better than trying to do predictive policing. So it was nice, I think, to see someone really dig into these issues and realize they're really socio-political ones, and not necessarily technical ones, a lot of the time.

books.title: The Lover
books.author: Marguerite Duras
books.notes: One of Alan's books, though I'd heard of it before, I think in Meander Spiral Explode, the book about alternative narrative structures.

books.title: Why Have Kids?
books.author: Jessica Valenti
books.notes: Quick, journalist read on the topic of parenting. A lot about the pressure to raise your kid perfectly, the debate of staying at home or going back to work (staying at home, while fine, does put you in financial precarity), a kind of constant torrent of 'you're not doing it right' that leads to people with kids being miserable. What did I get out of it? Mostly that parenting isn't a competition, and going back to work is probably safer for people long-term, and women's bodies are often treated pre-natally even when they're not, and people without kids are probably legitimately happier than those with, at least for a while. She also gets into political issues, like how in US we blame ourselves for not staying home with our kids when we should be blaming the system for not subsidizing quality childcare. Kind of a typical, let's do collective action instead of individual striving, vibe, which is good, but didn't necessarily leave me with anything concrete.

books.title: Three Wishes
books.author: Liane Moriarty
books.notes: This is added out of order -- I read it on the plane to Sydney on my Kindle. Moriarty books are always a good time, and this one about three twin sisters and their lives, as one dates a guy whose sister is sleeping with another's husband, and a scene at the beginning where one is pregnant but you spend the book being unsure which one it is. Just fun, intersecting plots, like a really good soap opera with better and more realistic character development.

books.title: Too Loud a Solitude
books.author: Bohumil Hrabal
books.notes: Surrealist novel about a man who spends all day compacting old books for the trash. Ray recommended it, and I loved it. On the last page you learn the man's lover is called Ilonka! Crazy! This documentation is out of order, I must have forgotten to add it to the list earlier. I was tickled by the book, which has no clear plot but it most like recollections. There is movement, as we learn about the man (who takes books home and crams them into his house) and learns that a new machine will put him out of business, and recounts his past.

books.title: Klara and the Sun
books.author: Kazuo Ishiguro
books.notes: Read this because Vivian lent it to me ages ago and then when I was in NY for a few days to go up to IBM I picked it up from my office so I'd have something to read on the train. I didn't love it at first, it had a similar, breath-y vibe to Never Let Me Go (which I never finished) and similarly I was frustrated by how much information about the world was being purposefully kept from me. It felt like looking at the world through gauze I just didn't know why, I didn't feel like it served a purpose, it went on too long for me. But I literally had nothing else to read and some down time at IBM with nothing else to do so I stuck with it and about half way through it did start to get more interesting, when we realize the 'portrait' of Josie is actually an AF and that Klara would be asked to inhabit and 'become' Josie if Josie dies. This suddenly made the book much more interesting than Klara's continual slightly-lacking understanding of a world the reader also doesn't know quite enough about. So I'm glad I stuck it through, because the idea of replacement was actually kind of interesting, seeing the mother want it as a kind of balm and also acknowledging that many people wouldn't accept it, not because Klara wouldn't be able to replicate Josie but because the knowledge of her not being Josie would get in the way of their love. So that was a fun idea. But I just can't really stand his writing, and probably reading a precis of the book would have given me 90% of what I got out of reading the whole thing.

books.title: Glitch Feminism
books.author: Legacy Russell
books.notes: I think I originally originally saw this at the bookstore near Max's place in Brooklyn, on the sandwich board outside the store, but didn't realize it was an actual book til later, when I put together a media studies / AI ethics reading list for the summer of 2022. This was on it, and it's the most artsy of the books I found, I think, a manifesto for taking the idea of glitch -- failings, errors, strangeness -- as a guiding principle for feminism to push against the norms of society. It's good, a little inside-the-art-world, with lots of references, but I liked the idea of seeing error or strangeness as a way to reclaim ourselves as important.

books.title: Revenge of the Scapegoat
books.author: Caren Beilin
books.notes: Kim recommended this to me on twitter when I asked for surrealist literature recs. It's a recent book, maybe somewhat autofictiony (in the notes she says the dialog in the book with Ray is mostly unchanged from her own dialog with real Ray.) It's a fun, strange book, with 'heart-stepping' cows, and her swollen feet talking as two characters from a Flaubert novel. The central line of the book is the narrator's need to escape from these letters her father had given her when she was a teenager which her brother recently sent to her as part of cleaning out the house. The letters, which are revealed only towards the end, are bad but crazy bad, and I think there's this great tension in the book about what's considered legit and who gets to claim scapegoat status and how insidious things can be fucked up and fuck people up.

books.title: Trust Exercise
books.author: Susan Choi
books.notes: One of the books from Alan's bookshelf. First part is too breathy, somehow written in a weird present tense I don't know the word for but has a lot of 'has' as in, They have been doing X, like present tense but also past. Also a lot of collective third person, making it super nostalgic and weird to read. Almost gave up about a quarter in but then it got interesting, following Sarah and David at an elite theatre school in LA, and Mr. Kingsley's making public of their private (tho high school so not that private affair). Then the English theatre class coming, and Sarah's brief sex with Liam. THEN the second part turns the whole first part on its head as a book written by Sarah, loosely based on her real experiences, and Karen, a character from the book, Sarah's actual best friend from high school, reading the book (and stopping partway?) and eventually acting out revenge on the teacher from the English theatre students who returns amidst sexual assault scandals to perform a play. We learn Karen got pregnant by Martin (the English teacher) in high school and ended up giving the kid up for adoption. This section is also written weirdly, but more enjoyably, in a mixed first- and third-person, as if Karen is trying to tell her own story from a distance. Final, tiny last part is from the perspective of Karen's kid, who is trying to find her birth parents, and in the process gets assaulted by a teacher from the theatre school. I had trouble placing that character; was he mentioned in the prior parts? He also but not quite fit the description of Mr. Kingsley, except not gay and Mr. Kingsley wasn't portrayed as an aggressor but maybe that was due to the perspective of the respective parts narrators, and not the truth.

books.title: Fiona and Jane
books.author: Jean Chen Ho
books.notes: Got recommended this novel on the reboot discord after I asked for recs for female friendship novels, because Alan had commented that I (he?) hadn't read many (maybe we were talking about the Ferrante novels?) and I realized I hadn't. I didn't love this book for the first third... it was okay, enjoyable  but didn't pull me along like some novels, and wasn't stylistically or structurally interesting. Still, I stuck with it, and really enjoyed it at the end, almost crying at one point. Follows two girls who become friends in primary school in LA, and follows their lives up til their forties, with some stretches apart (Fiona is in New York City for several years) where they don't talk too much. It really did center their friendship, though in the way friendship is so centered in many lives, it's a sideline but it's also a constant. Some details to help jog your memory: it opens with Jane visiting her father in Taiwan; he's decided to stay because he's realized he's gay and has fallen in love. Jane outs him to her mother, and feels responsible for his suicide many many years later. Jane's bi, and her first foray with a girl is with her piano teacher Ping. Fiona is raised by a single mother, who got pregnant by a college kid back in Taiwan but never told the father about the pregnancy. Fiona goes to UC Berkeley, and then NYU Law, drops out, but eventually many years later finishes up at UCLA. Jane never really does college, and ends up managing an apartment building in LA. Fiona dates Jasper during college, then goes with him to New York; he's a writer. Their close friend Kenji gets cancer. Jasper cheats on Fiona, but wants to figure it out; Fiona doesn't and we never really see why she won't. Fiona later on in LA marries Aaron, who also cheats on her I think. They get married quick, then divorced. Later she marries... who. Barry? Bobby. Jane dates a white girl called Carly for a while; Won helps Jane get over her. Later on we see Jane form a relationship with Julian, an ex marine, and Naima, a black screen writer. I forget if we get any of Jane's relationships in between... Anyway, in some ways the book is just these vignettes about their lives at different points, and I don't think they're all 100% in order, but it's most chronological. At the end Fiona is married with a kid, and Jane is thinking about getting serious with Naima, but it ends with them together, Jane getting over her guilt about her father, and suggesting she write a novel about Jane and Fiona's relationship. Kind of a cutsie ending, but it worked.

books.title: How Should a Person Be?
books.author: Sheila Heti
books.notes: Read this as part of my interest in autofiction. Something else inspired me... oh right, I'd been thinking about Sheila Heti since I got super into her New York Times substack-style thingo where she alphabetized her journals and published them. It was super interesting, but then I read the first few pages of Motherhood and it didn't really grab me. For some reason I turned to her again, probably because of my interest in autofiction, and found this at the library; the first page seemed good so I took it home. I really liked it. The narrator was compelling, this anxiety about authenticity and how to be herself was captivating, as was her relationship with Margauex (sp?) the painter. (It was a book about female friendship! Truly!) The only parts I didn't like were her detailing her relationship with Israel, which I found... not disturbing, but just... eh, it bothered me that she was so into ceding sexual control, even though it made sense with her whole anxiety about how to make choice and 'how to be'. Still, I didn't want her to succumb to this super traditional girl stereotype, and I didn't see her really interrogate that except adjacently. Also maybe I didn't like knowing if Israel really knew what was going on, was concious of his behavior, like was he playing into a kink or did he think girls just like that? I guess I didn't like that it was unclear if there was really consent. Anyway, the rest of it was super interesting, and now I'm curious to go back to Motherhood.

books.title: Convenience Store Woman
books.author: Sayaka Murata
books.notes: Read this all in one night, one of Alan's bookshelf reads. Super strange story about a woman who is perfectly happy to work at a convenience store for the rest of her life, though everyone in her life is concerned that she hasn't gotten a real job, nor any prospects for a husband or family. She enjoys the store because it's clear how she is meant to act and what she is meant to do; she's constantly trying to figure out what other people want from her, who all seem to be very concerned that's she's not 'cured'. She has a lean towards violence, that she represses because she sees it causes other people distress; as a child she hits a boy on the head with a spade because everyone wanted him to stop fighting, but she didn't understand why concussing him wasn't a reasonable solution. It seems like no one really understands her, maybe today or in the US we'd call her austistic and maybe be able to have a truly shared conversation about how she differs from others, but instead everyone just cries about how weird she is and she does her best to fit in, without abandoning what she wants, which mostly seems to be to serve the convenience store. I think there's a tension in the book about if we should read the narrator as a psychopath or a metaphor for not fitting in. I liked it; I found the narrator captivating, and it was a super quick read (I read it all in one night) and had plenty to think about when it was over.

books.title: The Deer
books.author: Dashiel Carrera
books.notes: Met Dashiel through Danny at CHI. The book is kind of in two parts, where the first is about a guy who is told he hit a deer while driving drunk in his home town after finding out his abusive father died; the second part is about a pair of siblings dealing with their mother dying. I enjoyed it's weird, surreal nature, but it never really answered any of the questions it brought up, like did the guy hit a deer, why was he running from the police. It kind of felt like watching a movie while you're falling asleep: there just wasn't enough information coming into to ever know what was happening. That's a move, totally, but I felt I wanted something to grasp onto, I didn't need everything resolved but it felt too dreamy and loopy and so I never was able to get into the story or the characters.

books.title: DMZ Colony
books.author: Don Mee Choi
books.notes: This had been sitting on my shelf partly read for a long time; I finally finished it. I feel I hadn't been reading poetry much, since I've been focusing on my thesis and also feeling a bit down and depressed about poetry and not getting published. Anyway, DMZ Colony is part poetry, part archival, with a lot of documents and stories from North Korean refugees (not sure if that's the right word) and how various people think about North and South Korea. It was good; dark, but good, with lots of images and some stuff in Korean that I obviously didn't get.

books.title: The Math of Saint Felix
books.author: Diane Exavier
books.notes: Diane's book! Like DMZ Colony, it sat on my shelf partially read for a long time. It's one long poem in sections, and it's quite good, Diane is amazing. There is a whalefall-esque poem that I was a bit miffed about --- did one of us steal the idea from the other? --- but it's significantly different from mine and I got over it eventually. It's a pleasant read, in that it's a thick book but a lot of the poems are slim, almost visual art with a few words strewn across the page. Parts of it are chunkier, but it didn't feel overwhelming to read.

books.title: Wonder Tissue
books.author: Hannah Larrabee
books.notes: Pretty good, not amazing, had it sitting on my shelf for a long time.

books.title: Beowulf
books.author: Beowulf poet
books.notes: Read this because it's a classic. The Seamus Heaney translation. A bit hard to follow at times, because I felt it would shift scenes somewhat suddenly, and we would now be in a story being told, or now back in the present action, and also I had trouble following all the characters and their relations, but decently enjoyable epic tale.

books.title: Mr. Kafka and other tales from the time of the cult
books.author: Bohumil Hrabal
books.notes: I liked them, but not as much as I liked Too Loud a Solitude. Also a bit hard to follow at times, though in a totally different way to Beowulf. The most memorable story went back and forth between this girl drinking herself to oblivion because she's been sentenced to jail and she gets picked up and raped by a group guys, and the parallel story are these professors just throwing junk into a big junk compressor. Just a lot of surreal weirdness like that; a guy making art in his basement without sleeping; taking down a statue that people still love because communist rule is gone (or here?), the surrealism of Eastern Europe (Hrabal is Czech, I think?) in the throws of governmental and societal changes that turned life upside down.

books.title: Queer Data
books.author: Kevin Guyan
books.notes: Great. Lots of interesting stuff here about census and data collection, when queer data is and isn't used for action, good and bad ways to ask about things like sexuality and gender, interesting tidbits about part census stuff, and being clear that more data isn't always good for queer communities. An academic book, but very readable and super interesting, like this fact about the US census asking about who's in your household and if you're married, which means two men (or women) could be heads of household and married and therefore it kind of accidentally collected gay marriage data but they decided to random swap the gender of one of the heads of household to ignore this fact.

books.title: Novelist as Vocation
books.author: Haruki Murakami
books.notes: Quick, easy read. Nice conversational style, and it was interesting to hear about his career and choices and approach to writing. I would say mostly I enjoyed this as motivation to write a novel, though I'm not sure I'll ever be a novelist as a vocation (I'm not sure I have the patience and stamina for it) I do want to write a novel, I always have since I was a kid, and reading this reminded me of my desire to do that and the effect and stamina and patience it takes, which I think I have in me, at least for a bit.

books.title: Agallas
books.author: Raina Telgemeier
books.notes: Read this on my phone with the Libby app. I read it in Spanish, so the going was slow, but I really liked it, as it follows the narrator through childhood (middle school ish?) and having a lot of anxiety and dealing with her best friend moving to another school, and kind of fighting with another girl at school who they end up becoming friends. It's a nice coming of age style memoir, though I'm sure that, reading it in Spanish, I missed a lot of the subtext and subtlty; it read like a young adult book to me, which maybe it is, but it may also be my limited understanding of Spanish. Still, I'm impressed I got through it, and I think it was a great way to practice Spanish, and she has several other books that I could read.

books.title: Chi Running
books.author: Danny Dreyer
books.notes: Read this after suffering with healing a hamstring strain on my left leg, after I thought I had figured out the hamstring insertion point tendonitis on my right side that had been giving me trouble for over five (!) years. Getting belly-of-the-hamstring strains on my left side was like... what? Come one. Anyway, so I wanted to read a bunch of books on form, after I got the strain and took some time off and went back to running and got the strain again. I looked up lists of books on form and picked out the four that seemed most relevant. I knew I had read Chi Running before, and had gotten rid of my copy in one of my book purges. Luckily Rodrigo had taken it and still had it! Rereading it, I started to remember it again: lead from the hips, keep the upper body straight and tall, lean forward to run faster, let the legs drop below the center of mass and pick them up behind you, rather than try to propel the legs forward. Keep the pelvis flat, don't let it tip up. Land midfoot (I don't think this is necessary all the time). Swing the arms back, and don't let them cross the midline. Keep you cadence constant and lengthen your stride to go faster. All good things, and I enjoyed rereading it and reminding myself of the ideas and paying attention to those ideas while running.

books.title: Anatomy for Runners
books.author: Jay Dicharry
books.notes: Similar to Chi Running, I read this to try to figure out my hamstring injury. Dicharry is more scientific than Dreyer, and also takes a wider perspective. Dreyer is pretty prescriptive: he's found a good form, you should follow it too. Dicharry talks a lot about diversity in runners; the same form won't work for everyone, because everyone has a different body. Dicharry focuses on the importance of cross-training and strengthening exercises, and how different deficiencies can cause injuries. He criticizes the Rest Ice Compress Elevate framework, and the idea that runners can just take time off running to let an injury to heal and not expect the injury to come back---instead we need to think about what caused the injury (often form or some kind deficiency) and correct that, as well as include exercise that helps healing. He goes into bone, cartilege, tendons, muscle, describing how they each contribute and work and might be harmed or healed. Muscles need some exercise to heal them, otherwise they just atrophy. At the end he has a series of tests to look for common deficiencies in runners; I failed the hip flexor test (most people do, because sitting a lot causes tight hip flexors) and the hamstring flexibility test (he says that, from lying on your back, you should be able to lift your leg to at least 70 degrees with minimal feeling of stretch; since my right hamstring injury I've avoided stretching my hamstrings basically ever so now they're kind of tight). Interestingly, I'm pretty sure I read this back when I was dating Oscar, I just forgot all about it! So even though I got my copy from the library, after I read it I bought a used copy online using Alibris, so I can keep it as a reference book.

books.title: Your Best Stride
books.author: Jonathan Beverly
books.notes: My third running form book. (The fourth, Tread Lightly, I didn't end up finishing it, it was a bit more all over the place, looking at the history of running shoes and all kinds of side narratives I didn't care that much about.) This one was more well-rounded than Chi Running, but less technical than Anatomy for Runners. (He actually cites both Dreyer and Dicharry.) He does report on studies, and lots of quotes from runners and coaches and scientists, but the whole thing was a bit more diffuse. At the end he offers up some running advice that he thinks cuts across the board, and it's good stuff like 'run tall', and 'run soft', things that you can try to achieve but also do what you want (rather than things like changing how you strike the ground which won't necessarily shift your body mechanics the way you expect).

books.title: Total Immersion
books.author: Terry Laughlin
books.notes: Brad recommended this to me as the book he read to learn how to swim. I really liked the idea of it, a focus on form because drag is such a big deal in swimming that reducing drag will make you much faster than swimming harder, and that by working on your form you're gain the strength you want along the way. I found the exercises at the end less exciting, they just felt kind of unnecessary, I felt like I could implement a lot of his ideas just by being conscious of my form while swimming. I guess I also don't feel my form is holding me back too much, and I don't care too much about speed (or even necessarily efficiency). Anyway, he talks about the importance of keeping your hips up (obvious) and that you need to press your chest down (I find this is easeist by looking down more) to get your hips to buoy up. Then the idea of gliding forward with the arm out ahead, as if you're trying to fit your body through the smallest hole it can go. The hips and torso should shift quite a lot, because there's less drag on your side than on your front, and your legs don't need to kick that much. I read some critiques online that the book is great for getting you into swimming, but eventually if you want to go faster it's not necessarily the fastest form. Anyway, I got a lot out of it, even if I didn't end up doing the drills.

books.title: Remainder
books.author: Tom McCarthy
books.notes: Read this for the Laura/Hansa/et al book club. About a guy who gets hit by something in a freak accident he can't talk about, because he receives a huge (8.5 million pound) settlement to never discuss it. But the accident puts him in the hospital and PT for months, relearning how to walk and pick things up. He comes out of it kind of empty, not remembering much of his past, not sure what to do with all his money. He's concerned with authenticity, and how he doesn't feel real, but when he watches a movie with his friend he says the actors seem so authentic, everything they do so perfect, which his friend disagrees with, no, the actors are fake! No one is perfect like that. Still, the narrator is so unsure of himself, and finds his actions empty. At a party he goes to the bathroom and notices a crack along the wall; it brings back to him a vivid memory he can't quite place of being in a flat with the smell of cooked liver coming up through the window, and a pianist practicing a piece, and red sloping roofs on the apartment building next door he can see from the window, with black cats lazing about. He goes about using his money to recreate this memory perfectly: acquiring a renovating a building, hiring people to act. He feels most real and authentic when he relives (re-enacts) this memory, which he can practice and perfect and experiece over and over again, or slower this time. He then starts to re-enact other things: an experience he has getting his car fixed, a shooting that happens near the auto shop, eventually a bank robbery. It escalates; he wants to re-enact the bank robbery but for real, at a real bank; Naz, the man who makes everything happen for him, notes that they can't tell the re-enactors, that they might have to kill them afterwards to keep the reality of the situation safe. The narrator is clearly going mad, losing track of reality or stopping to care for reality much at all. In the bank robbery re-enactment that's actually real, a man trips and falls, because in the recreation they made there was a wrinkle in the rug; in reality there is no wrinkle, but the re-enactor had practiced falling on the wrinkle; without the wrinke he falls for real, accidentally pulling the trigger on his gun and shooting another re-enactor. The re-enactors start to freak, realizing it's real, escaping to the warehouse, where the narrator re-enacts the trip and really shoots another man... Naz and the narrator are attempting to escape via private jet, but get called back by the control station; the narrator tells them to keep going, says to say that it's a hijacking, thinking in some way that he's acting out the hijacking, rather than doing the hijacking, or maybe he's stopped telling the difference. He asks them to turn back, but then turn back again, doing figure of eights, and we end in this moment of suspension, like a moment earlier in the book where he's going to pick up a friend from the airport and keeps turning to go home and then turning to go to the train because he can't decide if he needs to go get her plane number. The book is strange, an exploration not, I think, of happiness (as someone blurbed it to be about) but of authenticity and reality. What makes us feel in the moment? Perhaps the narrator stopped having moments to be in. Strangely his idea of feeling authentic is the opposite of most, I think, who find authenticity in spontaneity. Instead he finds it in rehearsal, which is the only time he feels real, perhaps because through his PT he stopped feeling like normal actions, walking, eating, where easy; instead they demanded his attention. What does it mean to live a life where spontaneity or presence can only happen in a completely controlled and pre-defined situation? Interested to talk to people about it. I'm not sure I actually liked the book, I just find it fascinating.

books.title: The Hurting Kind
books.author: Ada Limóm
books.notes: I read this for the Reboot poetry book club, though I ended up not attending the actual book club because it overlapped with my lunch with Lia. Still, I liked the book, which I got from the library because I'm pretty sure it's only out in hard cover. Limón is excellent, her poems short and simple but never boring, never flat. This book lives a lot in nature, though I love the poem in which she describes how she used to not care about birds, blue bird, black bird, blah blah blah bird. There is one poem about not being a mother, but mostly the book centres on daily life, parents/grandparents/ancestory, love, sadness, the typical poetry beats, though of course Limón is doing it so well they don't feel normal, they don't feel typical.

books.title: Whale Fall
books.author: David Baker
books.notes: Got this from the library because, well, I had titled my manuscript the same! The whole book isn't about whale fall; instead it's a long poem in the middle. The poems are good; lots of nature poems, poems about children, for the most part that kind of clarity and poignancy I expect in poetry, though the long whale fall poem is more askance, harder to follow the 'plot', though mixed with science and other learnings that I enjoyed. (He even mentions SnotBot!! Amazing!!) I was ready to not like it, but actually I did, and I'd consider buying a copy.

books.title: Dando Vueltas por tu Interior
books.author: Inkoherente
books.notes: A kind of strange, self-reflective comic-y book that I found at the library when I was looking for graphic novels in Spanish. It has not too many words---which is why I picked it up---but the words are weird and kind of tricky (things like, If you meet yourself, don't walk away from yourself, or stuff like that that are just a bit weird to parse) so it turns out it wasn't that easy of a read in Spanish, but at least it was short!

books.title: The Argonauts
books.author: Maggie Nelson
books.notes: Read this on the plane to Sydney. It was just as good at the first time, and I think I got more of the references this time. I had forgotten how much is about trying to get pregnant with donor sperm. I liked the philosophy, and the questions of how motherhood and domesticity impacts work. It's very much steeped in women's / queer / gender studies, which is something I've never personally studied but I enjoy reading about. I liked the anecdote about a Renaissance researcher who, after having a child, finds her research to be incredibly boring in comparison, but, after two years, returns to finding her work interesting again.

books.title: The Creativity Code
books.author: Marcus du Sautoy
books.notes: Read this because it's on a similar topic to my book proposal topic. It's a nice, nonfiction book about if machines can be creative by a mathematician. It's well-written, though I found some of the mathematical explanations not that easy to follow, and covers a wide range of machine creations: alphago, image recognition and generation (deep dream), language generation, music generation, and the one I knew least about, mathematics. My feeling was that the book was too broad and surface level, but also I know a lot about this stuff so maybe for another reader it was just right. And I did get something out of it; though I had heard of most of what he talked about, there was occasionally something I hadn't heard of, which is always good. There was one text generation project, a NaNoGenMo entry, that he described as giving some insight into a machine trying to make sense of text from Wikipedia. At the end of the book he has a similar take to me---art is a communicative act that requires intention and experience and propulsion and computers don't have that---and what he liked about the NaNoGenMo project was it gave some insight into the 'mind' of the machine. Hm, what else. He seemed to be back and forth on if a computer could be creative, on one hand seeming to say yes, clearly they create impressive artifacts, and on the other claiming humans can be the only true source. But I guess that's the truth.

books.title: The Forest for the Trees
books.author: Betsy Lerner
books.notes: Picked this up at the library when I was picking up some other books and noticed it, remembering that the agent Angel brought into our class mentioned reading it and that set her on her path to become an agent. I liked the first part a lot, where she describes writers as having a need to write, and that writing gives back very little, so only those who really feel the need tend to end up going for it. She talks about the need to write what you are going to write, and that no one can really tell you what to write, and chasing fads is useless, so you might as well do your own thing. She gets into drugs and mental illness; slightly less interesting to me, and here the book began to drag a bit, lots of stories about writers who did and didn't self-promote. I mean, basically there's a million ways to carve the cow (or whatever that idiom is), and it's interesting really only as comfort and maybe a bit of confidence that your way (my way?) has a good a chance of any. It got a little more interesting toward the end, with the details of publishers and editors and publicists, but I think nothing too too new or unknown for me. I was on a plane while reading it, I didn't have much choice, but I also felt some compulsion to finish it, because there were good gems and so when it dragged I was hopefully it might shine again, and it often did, if not as often as I wanted.

books.title: The Artist in the Machine
books.author: Arthur I. Miller
books.notes: Read this as a 'competing title' for the book proposal I'm working on (based on my PhD work). I found the first section really frustrating; he seems to randomly define creativity (apparently he's a creativity researcher?) with a bunch of attributes and then gives anecdotes of famously 'creative' people to back it up. But all the creative people are dead white guys. The only contemporary people he talks about are tech CEOs, as if Mark Zuckerberg and Jeff Bezos are the creative geniuses of our generation. He mentions maybe Emily Dickinson? And some 'husband-and-wife' teams. Anyway, so I thought that part was shit. But it was a short part at the start. Most of the book reads like a summary of talking to a bunch of different people in AI art, which is pretty interesting and he did talk to a lot of people across a lot of different mediums and genres. He always ends a chapter with whether that person thinks computers can be creative or not. Then the last section is some research on consciousness and why he thinks computers will soon become conscious and truly be creative like people. He had this whole thing about thinking it's good for computers to be creative, even more creative than people, but I didn't quite understand why he was so excited about the singularlity. Anyway, worth reading, but not really my cup of tea.

books.title: A Kinder Sea
books.author: Felicity Plunkett
books.notes: Bought this in Sydney, at Abbey's Bookstore near the QVB. I just wanted to buy some Australian poetry book, and this one caught my eye given the whole ocean thing, but also I liked some of the poems I read. And the book was fine, a lot about the sea but not strictly. She talks about how 'a kinder sea' is from a phrase commonly attributed to Emily Dickinson but actually she never said it, someone else did. I ddin't love love it, but I did think it was nice.

books.title: Gender Queer
books.author: Maia Kobabe
books.notes: Picked this up for the library on a whim. Quick read, but I really enjoyed it; memoir about discovering gender queerness and also asexuality and I thought just did a cool job of exploring how unique and individual everyone's path to / around gender and sexuality is.

books.title: Sea and Fog
books.author: Etel Adnan
books.notes: Loved this. Bought this at the Guggenheim, second time I saw it there, after I didn't see a used copy anywhere else. Meditative prose poems about, well, sea and fog, but eventually gets into more modern times referants. Hard to describe. Made me think a bit of Agua Viva in its plotlessness but also how it captivated me and its beauty.
